questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for evaluation of multiple prior episodes of sunburn. According to his mother, the patient gets more easily sunburned and has a lighter skin tone as compared with his siblings. The patient’s family immigrated to the United States 2 years ago, and they previously had limited access to healthcare. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 97/68 mmHg, and pulse is 77/min. He is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination reveals diffuse milky-white hair and skin. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:
 
 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  15.6 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  47% 
 Leukocytes  7,200/mm3 
 Platelets  190,000/mm3 

Genetic testing reveals reduced tyrosinase activity. Which of the following conditions is the patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient has albinism, which is characterized by a drastic reduction or complete lack of pigmentation in the hair, skin, and eyes. The condition arises due to congenital defects in tyrosinase, the enzyme that produces melanin, or impaired transport of tyrosine and melanosomes.  

Patients can have milky-white hair and skin. In addition, patients can have very light blue or translucent irises, which appear red because of the retinal tissue lining the back of the eye. The absence of melanin in the eyes causes a variety of vision problems, including impaired depth perception, reduced visual acuity, nystagmus, and amblyopia. Moreover, albinism can cause freckles, moles, and lentigines to form on the skin; the lack of melanin and exposure to intense ultraviolet radiation increases the risk of developing skin cancer.  

Albinism is also seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which can cause pancytopenia, recurrent infections, and peripheral neuropathy. Of note, this patient does not have Chediak-Higashi syndrome, since his blood cell counts are normal.  

Treatment involves preventing additional ailments arising from the lack of protection normally conferred by melanin. Prevention includes wearing tinted glasses for eye protection and sunscreen to reduce the risk of skin cancer. Nitisinone, a medication that increases tyrosine levels, can be used to treat certain forms of albinism.


Option Analysis

❌ Recurrent Staphylococcal infections:
Incorrect: This complication would likely develop in patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome, which is due to a defect in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene. The condition can cause albinism, pancytopenia, recurrent infections, and peripheral neuropathy. In contrast, this patient’s blood count shows normal hemoglobin, platelet, and leukocyte levels, making Chediak-Higashi syndrome unlikely.  
❌ Intellectual disability :
Incorrect: Intellectual disability may develop in patients with phenylketonuria, which occurs due to imapired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. Patients can develop a musty odor, eczema, fair complexion, intellectual disability, and seizures. In contrast, this patient’s genetic testing reveals a defect in the tyrosinase enzyme. 
✅  Reduced visual acuity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Early onset arthritis:
Incorrect: Early-onset arthritis may be a complication of alkaptonuria, which is due to a congenital defect in homogentisate oxidase. As a result, homogentisic acid accumulates in the body and can damage cartilage. Additional symptoms include bluish-black ear cartilage and sclera. 
❌ Peripheral neuropathy:
Incorrect: Patients with Chediak-Higashi syndrome can develop peripheral neuropathy. Chediak-Higashi syndrome is due to a defect in the lysosomal trafficking regulator gene, and it can be a cause of albinism. However, patients with this condition also develop pancytopenia. In contrast, this patient’s hemoglobin, leukocyte, and platelet counts are within normal limits.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for burns sustained to his thighs and palms of the hands while playing with matches in a garage. The patient weighs 48 kg and has a height of 135 cm. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 80/min, respirations 20/min, and blood pressure 105/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals bilateral circumferential wounds from ankle to mid-thigh and burns on both palms. The patient is admitted to the burn unit and initiated on intravenous fluids and a topical antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of bacitracin?

choices.text: Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall
Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors
Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit
Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane

questions.solution:
This patient has sustained partial thickness burns on the hands and legs and is being treated with an antibiotic ointment containing bacitracin. Bacitracin is an antibiotic agent active against gram-positive cocci, including Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Streptococcus pyogenes. It inhibits bactoprenol phosphate, a transmembrane transporter embedded within the bacterial cell membrane. Bactoprenol phosphate promotes the transport of N-acetyl-muramic acid and N-acetyl mucopeptides that form components of the bacterial cell wall. Bacitracin inhibits the transport of these mucopeptides and inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Bacitracin is commonly used for topical application in partial thickness burns, particularly those that involve the face and the perineum, and for photokeratitis. Topical agents are used cautiously in patients with impaired renal function and neurotoxic or nephrotoxic adverse effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibits dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase, an enzyme that is involved in folate synthesis. It is bacteriostatic when combined with trimethoprim. However, it is not used topically in the treatment of burns.  
❌ Binds to transpeptidases and inhibits cross-linking of peptidoglycan in bacterial cell wall:
Incorrect: Penicillin and modified penicillins are beta-lactam antibiotics that bind to transpeptidases and inhibit cross-linking within the cell wall.  
❌ Inhibits peptidoglycan cell wall formation by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors:
Incorrect: Vancomycin directly binds to D-Ala D-Ala portions of the cell wall. It is a systemic agent in treating MRSA (+) skin and soft tissue infections. In the absence of a previous episode of MRSA or lack of clinical improvement in 48 hours, IV vancomycin is not likely indicated.  
❌ Blocks peptidyl transferase at 50s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: Chloramphenicol is an antimicrobial agent that targets the 50s ribosomal subunit. Its use is limited due to the hematologic toxicity associated with its use. Gentamicin (which targets the initiation complex of the 30s subunit) can be used topically.  
✅ Inhibits transport of peptidoglycan proteins across the cell membrane:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a left arm burn injury. The patient was camping when he accidently set his tent on fire while cooking inside the vestibule. While attempting to put the fire out, he sustained a deep burn to his left forearm. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 177/90 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. Physical examination reveals a circumferential eschar to the left forearm with exposed fat and muscle. The overlying skin feels tense to palpation. Which of the following acute complications is this patient at the greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a full thickness (third degree) circumferential forearm burn. He should be evaluated for limb ischemia with skin examination and assessment of distal pulses. Circumferential, full-thickness burns, can produce a tourniquet effect which can compromise limb circulation. Therefore, this patient is at significant risk of developing distal limb ischemia and necrosis. Prompt intervention with escharotomy is required.

Severe burns can be limb or life-threatening. The first step in evaluating a patient presenting with a significant burn is to perform the ABCDE assessment to determine if they are stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, acute management involves stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Next, IV access should be obtained and fluids should be started. Care should be taken to avoid the injured extremity when obtaining IV access and placing a blood pressure cuff or arterial line. Fluid resuscitation should be provided according to the Parkland formula.  

Option Analysis

✅ Distal limb ischemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemorrhagic shock:
Incorrect: Hemorrhagic shock is not a likely complication of this patient’s burn as he is not losing blood. He has a circumferential full thickness burn with eschar on the arm which can lead to distal limb ischemia.  
❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia can occur in the acute phase of a burn injury. Acutely, this patient is at the greatest risk of developing limb ischemia.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia and not hypoglycemia is typically seen in patients with severe burns. Acutely, this patient is at the greatest risk of developing limb ischemia.  
❌ Osteomyelitis:
Incorrect: Chronic osteomyelitis can result later on from deep burns. However, acutely this patient is at the greatest risk of developing limb ischemia.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the office because of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough for the past two months. She reports that she often has to stop to catch her breath after climbing a flight of stairs to her apartment complex. She has seasonal allergies, for which she takes over-the-counter medications. Review of systems reveals occasional joint pain in the ankles and knees and painful swellings on the shins. The remainder of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness of the knees and ankles and tender, immobile, erythematous nodules on the shins bilaterally. Chest x-ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. CT-guided transbronchial biopsy is shown:


Reproduced from Flickr

Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s dermatologic lesions on the shins?

choices.text: Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to a contact allergen
Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics

questions.solution:
This patient presents with tender, erythematous shin nodules, exertional dyspnea, nonproductive cough, and arthralgias, together with a hilar lymph node biopsy demonstrating noncaseating granulomas. This presentation is diagnostic for sarcoidosis, a chronic granulomatous autoimmune disorder. The tender, erythematous nodules on her shins are most likely erythema nodosum (EN), which is a common dermatologic manifestation of sarcoidosis among other conditions (e.g., streptococcal infection, tuberculosis, coccidioidomycosis, histoplasmosis, hepatitis B, inflammatory bowel disease, and drugs, including oral contraceptives and penicillin).

EN is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction resulting in immune-complex deposition in the subcutaneous fat, causing inflammation. It classically manifests as erythematous, tender, immobile nodules on the shins bilaterally. It may follow a prodrome of malaise, fever, and upper respiratory tract infection. Diagnosis is usually clinical, but biopsy may be performed in case of an atypical presentation. It is a self-limited condition and usually resolves within a few weeks.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Type IV hypersensitivity reaction to a contact allergen:
Incorrect: Allergic contact dermatitis results from a type IV hypersensitivity reaction to contact allergens like nickel, chromium, cobalt, and poison ivy. It presents with well-demarcated, erythematous papules or vesicles with chronic lichenification. Although erythema nodosum is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, it does not appear in response to a contact allergen.
✅ Inflammation of subcutaneous fat cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics:
Incorrect: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics by Streptococcus pyogenes results in erysipelas. This condition manifests as a sharply-demarcated, fiery red, painful plaque at the site of bacterial entry. Presence of tender nodules on the shins with a non-caseating granuloma on lung biopsy suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Keratinocyte detachment within stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by bacterial exotoxin-induced destruction of keratinocytes resulting in their detachment in the stratum granulosum. The condition is characterized by a cutaneous, erythematous rash with sloughing and constitutional symptoms. Tender, erythematous nodules on shins would be atypical.
❌ Mast cell degranulation:
Incorrect: Acute urticaria, which presents with pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous wheals, results from mast cell degranulation. Tender nodules on the shins with difficulty breathing would be atypical.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the office for the evaluation of a rash on her knees bilaterally. The rash has been present for the past two months with intermittent itching, which has not improved with over-the-counter topical ointments. Past medical history is significant for inflammatory bowel disease, which is treated with 5-aminosalicylic acid. The rest of the history is noncontributory. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a silver, scaly, erythematous plaque on the knees bilaterally that bleeds mildly on removing the scales. Which of the following histological findings are most likely to be seen on skin biopsy of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with silver, scaly, erythematous plaques on the knees with occasional pruritus, together with a positive Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding when scales are removed). This presentation is suggestive of psoriasis, an autoimmune skin disease that results from T helper cell activation and immature proliferation of keratinocytes.

Psoriasis usually presents with a well-defined, erythematous plaque with overlying silvery scales that bleeds when scraping off. It is found to be associated with psoriatic arthritis, nail pitting, and is more prevalent in those with comorbidities such as diabetes, hypertension, and inflammatory bowel disease. Diagnosis is usually clinical, but biopsy is required when the diagnosis is unclear. Classic histopathological findings of psoriasis include:

  •  Hyperkeratosis: increased thickness of stratum corneum 
  •  Parakeratosis: retention of nuclei in stratum corneum 
  •  Acanthosis (image A): epidermal hyperplasia 
  •  Munro microabscesses (image B): collection of neutrophils in the stratum corneum of epidermis  
  •  Thin or absent stratum granulosum 
  •  Dilated and tortuous dermal capillaries 
  •  Perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate 

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

First line treatment options include topical corticosteroids (e.g. diflorasone) and vitamin D analog (e.g., calcipotriene, calcitriol).  

Option Analysis

❌ Separation of epidermal cells:
Incorrect: Acantholysis, the separation of epidermal cells, is typical of pemphigus vulgaris, which results from IgG antibodies against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. It typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the silver, scaly plaques on knees (extensor surface) as seen in this patient.
❌ Increased thickness of stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Hypergranulosis, the increased thickness of stratum granulosum, is characteristic of lichen planus, which presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. Silvery-scales on the lesion are not commonly seen.
✅ Increase thickness of stratum corneum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Squamous cell dysplasia:
Incorrect: Squamous cell dysplasia is seen in actinic keratosis, which presents as small (less than one centimeter), erythematous macules or papules on sun-exposed areas. Silver scaling on plaques is not seen.
❌ Thinning of epidermis:
Incorrect: Epidermal thinning and progressive dermal thickening is typical of scleroderma, which usually presents with skin thickening and hardening, mainly involving the fingers, hands, and face. Silver, scaly, pruritic plaques on the extensor surfaces would be atypical.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to the office because of flaky, itchy, white scales on the scalp. He is unable to recall its onset but states that it has been bothering him for “a while now.” He washes his scalp with mild shampoo once every two days and his face with cold water twice daily. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. During the encounter, he repeatedly scratches his face over the area between the nose and the mouth. Physical examination shows greasy scaliness of the skin of the face and the area behind the ear as shown:  


 Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons


Reproduced from: flickr.com


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with flaky and itchy white scales on the scalp (dandruff) and well-demarcated, erythematous, scaly lesions on the naso-labial folds and behind the ears. This presentation is consistent with seborrheic dermatitis.

Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic dermatological condition affecting the parts of skin with abundant sebaceous glands, although sebum production in the affected areas is typically normal. It has a bimodal incidence occurring in infants and adults and is thought to result from decreased T helper cell response to Malassezia species or their byproducts.

Commonly affected areas include the scalp (dandruff), face (in the skin folds around eyebrows, nasolabial folds, and external ear canal/posterior ear), chest, intertriginous areas, interscapular area, and umbilicus. Dandruff is the most common presentation, which can be asymptomatic or present as mild pruritus. In severe cases, it may present as greasy scales with salmon-coloured or grayish-white plaques. It tends to get worse in times of stress, or during winter, and improves in the summer.

Seborrheic dermatitis is sometimes associated with Parkinson disease and human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. The topical antifungal ketoconazole and ciclopirox are both effective for the condition.



Cradle cap

Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is an immune-mediated hyperproliferative disorder that causes pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous lesions with silver-scaling. Extensor areas (knee and elbows) are most commonly affected. Greasy scales on the face are atypical.
❌ Atopic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory disease that is often associated with personal or family history of atopy. In adults, it usually manifests as dry, thickened, pruritic flexural surfaces (mainly neck, ante-cubital fossa, popliteal fossa, wrists, and forearms). Greasy, erythematous lesions with a flaky scalp would be atypical.
❌ Rosacea:
Incorrect: Rosacea is a dermatologic condition that presents with ocular and cutaneous manifestations, commonly in individuals with lightly pigmented skin. Cutaneous symptoms include telangiectasias, papules, and pustules on the central face with minimal or no scaling. Scalp involvement is not usually seen.
❌ Tinea capitis:
Incorrect: Tinea capitis is a fungal infection of the scalp which presents with pruritic, scaly, erythematous patches that are associated with hair loss, residual black dots, and/or cervical lymphadenopathy. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis unlikely.
✅ Seborrheic dermatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the office for the evaluation of a skin rash. He reports that initially, there was a singular pruritic, salmon-colored patch that appeared on his back ten days ago. After two days, the patch slowly began to clear centrally. Approximately four days after the appearance of the initial rash, multiple similar but smaller lesions started to appear on his back and chest. Review of systems is significant for malaise and headache. Past medical history is significant for a recent cold that resolved spontaneously two weeks ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination findings are shown.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following best describes the progression of this patient’s skin rashes in the next several weeks?
questions.solution:
This patient with a recent history of a common cold presents with a pruritic, salmon-colored rash followed by the development of multiple similar, but smaller, rashes on his back in the distribution of cleavage lines. He is most likely suffering from pityriasis rosea (PR).

PR is an acute, self-resolving skin exanthem thought to result from a human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) reactivation. It is common among older children and young adults, and a prodrome of pharyngitis, malaise, and headache may be observed. It clinically presents with a one to two centimeter pink or salmon-colored, scaly patch with subsequent central clearing and cigarette paper-like scaly edges, also referred to as a “herald” patch (Fig A) or a “collarette" of scale affecting the neck, back or chest. This rash is followed by the development of smaller, macular rashes in the classic “Christmas tree” distribution following cleavage/tension lines. Diagnosis is based on history and clinical appearance. Most patients do not require therapy, except for occasionally a medium potency topical corticosteroid for itching. The rash spreads centrifugally (moving away from the center) and disappears within 6-8 weeks after desquamation.


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
Fig A

Option Analysis

✅ Spontaneous resolution:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulceration and bleeding:
Incorrect: Pyogenic granuloma, a polypoid capillary hemangioma, rapidly grows in size and can bleed and ulcerate. It appears commonly on lip or oral mucosa and is associated with pregnancy and trauma. A pruritic, scaly, erythematous rash suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Formation of bullae:
Incorrect: Formation of bullae is characteristic of bullous pemphigoid, an autoimmune blistering disease. A pre-bullous prodrome, however, presents as urticarial or eczematous lesions, not a centrally clearing “herald” patch.
❌ Progression to squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion which can progress to cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It usually presents with less than one centimeter erythematous macules or papules, with or without scaling, on sun-exposed areas. Physical examination shows a sand-paper-like, rough texture on palpation. In contrast, a “herald” patch on the back with smaller crops in the direction of cleavage lines is atypical.
❌ Color variegation:
Incorrect: Color variegation (variable mixtures of brown, tan, red, and black) is a common feature of melanoma and is a usual finding of evolving nevi. Variation in color is not typically observed in pityriasis rosea.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old boy is brought to the office because of a recurrent pruritic rash on his body. His parent first noticed a few lesions 4 days ago that disappeared within 2 hours. On subsequent days, similar but widespread lesions occurred that improved within a few hours without any intervention. His parent states he has not had any fevers, fatigue, or loss of appetite recently. He recently started gradually weaning off breast milk exclusively and eats boiled eggs for breakfast. He was born via spontaneous vaginal delivery, and his parent reports he has been healthy with no medical conditions. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows well-demarcated, raised, erythematous plaques as shown:


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics

questions.solution:
This infant presents with recurrent pruritus and a raised, erythematous, self-resolving rash following the initiation of eggs in his diet. He is most likely suffering from urticaria, a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The underlying mechanism involves mast cell degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators following a trigger which, in turn, increases vascular permeability, causing dermal edema and the typical appearance of a wheal. Urticaria is characterized by itchy, burning or stinging, erythematous, raised plaques with well-defined margins and pale centers. Urticaria can be acute (< 24 hours) or chronic (> 6 weeks).

Common triggers of urticaria can be described by five I’s:

  •  Infection (bacterial/viral/fungal/parasitic) 
  •  Injection of a drug/insect venom 
  •  Inhaled substances (e.g., pollen, mold, dust) 
  •  Ingestion of certain food (e.g. eggs), drugs, or chemicals 
  • Internal disease process such as an autoimmune disorder
Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance, though patch testing can be performed to confirm and determine the allergen. Treatment options include avoidance of triggers, symptomatic management of pruritus with antihistamines, or corticosteroids in severe cases.

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis:
Incorrect: Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) inhibitors, aspirin, and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs act by inhibiting the synthesis of prostaglandin, deviating the metabolism of arachidonic acid towards leukotrienes. These medications can result in increased vascular permeability, causing chronic idiopathic urticaria. This patient, however, has no history of COX-1 inhibitor ingestion.
✅ Mast cell degranulation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics:
Incorrect: Infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics by Streptococcus pyogenes results in erysipelas. This condition usually manifests as sharply-demarcated, fiery red, painful plaques and fever. It lasts for days without treatment, unlike the transient nature of this patient’s presentation.
❌ Keratinocyte detachment within stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is caused by bacterial exotoxin-induced detachment among keratinocytes from the stratum granulosum. Clinically, it is characterized by an erythematous rash with sloughing and constitutional symptoms (fever, fatigue, loss of appetite). This patient’s transient erythematous plaques are instead suggestive of acute urticaria.
❌ T cell-mediated release of cytokines:
Incorrect: Allergic contact dermatitis results from T cell-mediated release of cytokines (type IV hypersensitivity reaction) to contact allergens like nickel, chromium, cobalt, and poison ivy. It presents with well-demarcated, erythematous papules or vesicles with chronic lichenification. Egg ingestion would not cause contact dermatitis.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents to the office because of a rash and burning sensation on her hands. It started two days ago and is scaly and nonpruritic. She works as a gardener but recently started a new part-time house cleaning service near her neighborhood. Past medical history is significant for a streptococcal throat infection three weeks ago, treated with oral penicillin. She has taken warfarin regularly for the past three years after undergoing prosthetic aortic valve replacement. Family history is significant for atopic dermatitis in her mother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown.


Reproduced from Flickr

Which of the following factors most likely triggered this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s erythema, scaling, and burning of the hands after starting work cleaning houses is most likely due to a detergent causing contact dermatitis. Contact dermatitis is a localized inflammatory skin reaction that results from either exposure to allergens (allergic contact dermatitis), such as poison ivy, or irritants (irritant contact dermatitis), such as detergents.



Option Analysis

❌ Sun-exposure:
Incorrect: Sun-exposure is a major triggering factor for rosacea. It is a dermatologic condition that presents with ocular and cutaneous manifestations, commonly in individuals with lightly pigmented skin. Cutaneous symptoms include telangiectasias, papules, and pustules on the central face with minimal or no scaling. Hand involvement is uncommon.
✅ Detergent:
Correct: See Man Explanation.
❌ Pollen grains:
Incorrect: Pollen grains are allergens that can trigger the development of atopic dermatitis (AD) in susceptible individuals. Although a positive family history may contribute to the development of AD in this individual, it usually involves flexural areas. Involvement of the palms with scaly skin and fissures would be unlikely.
❌ Penicillin:
Incorrect: Ingestion of penicillin can cause a serum sickness-like reaction in some individuals, which manifests as fever, urticaria, and polyarthralgia one to two weeks after exposure. Although this patient had a recent penicillin exposure, none of the serum sickness symptoms are present in this patient.
❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect: Warfarin intake can rarely result in skin necrosis, which initially presents with pain and can progress to bullae and skin necrosis. It mostly occurs weeks after starting the therapy. This patient has been on warfarin for three years without any adverse events, making warfarin an unlikely cause.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the office because of a rash on his left arm. He states it appeared approximately six months ago and is scaly in appearance. He reports occasional itching over the rash, which fails to improve with over-the-counter emollients and moisturizing lotions. He has no chronic conditions and takes no medication regularly. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. BMI is 22 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings of the left forearm are shown:


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Biopsy and histopathology of the lesions reveals hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, acanthosis, and tortuous, dilated dermal papillary capillaries. Which of the following additional features can be seen in association with this dermatologic condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a chronic silver, scaly, pruritic plaque on his elbow, with failure to improve with emollients. He is likely suffering from psoriasis, a chronic autoimmune skin disease. Psoriasis can be associated with psoriatic arthritis (deforming joint disease), nail pitting, as well as psychiatric and psychosocial disorders.

In susceptible individuals, psoriasis results from the activation of T helper cells, dendritic cells and cytokines secondary to a disrupted skin barrier (trauma, infection and genetics), with subsequent immature proliferation of keratinocytes. This process leads to epidermal hyperplasia, parakeratosis (retention of nuclei), and hyperkeratosis (increased thickness) of stratum corneum, which then manifests as erythematous plaques with silvery scales. These scales, when picked off, cause localized bleeding spots (Auspitz sign) due to dermal blood vessel injury. The Koebner phenomenon – the appearance of new skin lesions on previously unaffected skin secondary to trauma – is also observed in psoriasis.

Common subtypes of psoriasis include:

  •  Plaque psoriasis (Fig A): The most common subtype, presents with symmetrically distributed, erythematous plaques with sharp-demarcation. Pruritus may be present. It commonly affects the scalp, extensor elbows, knees, and gluteal cleft. 
  •  Guttate psoriasis (Fig B): Appears as small, red, individual spots on the trunk and limbs, with onset in childhood, triggered by streptococcal throat infection. 
  •  Inverse psoriasis (Fig C): Affects the intertriginous areas including axilla and genital region. 
  •  Pustular psoriasis: Appears as areas of erythema and widespread superficial pustules. 
  • Erythrodermic psoriasis: The most severe subset, presents with generalized erythema and scaling.

Figure A (Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons)


Figure B (Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons)


Figure C (Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons)

Diagnosis is clinical, but biopsy may be indicated in some cases. First-line treatment options include topical corticosteroids (e.g. diflorasone) and vitamin D analog (e.g., calcipotriene, calcitriol).  

Option Analysis

❌ Insulin resistance:
Incorrect: Insulin resistance is commonly associated with acanthosis nigricans, which is an epidermal hyperplasia that presents with hyperpigmented skin thickening on the neck or axilla. A scaly, pruritic plaque on the elbow suggests an alternative diagnosis.
❌ Pill-rolling tremor:
Incorrect: A pill-rolling tremor is a characteristic feature of Parkinson disease, which is found to be associated with seborrheic dermatitis (SD). SD ranges in presentation from mild scaliness in the scalp (dandruff) to involving a wide area of skin as well-demarcated, erythematous, greasy, scaly lesions. A silver, scaly plaque on an extensor surface is indicative of psoriasis.
❌ Pulmonary fibrosis:
Incorrect: Pulmonary fibrosis is one of the complications of systemic sclerosis, which usually presents with skin thickening and hardening, mainly involving the fingers, hands, and face. A silver, scaly, pruritic plaque on the elbow would be atypical.
❌ Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection:
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is most commonly associated with oropharyngeal carcinoma and warts, which are small, cauliflower-like outgrowths that can appear on any part of the body. A silver, scaly, pruritic plaque on the elbow is instead suggestive of psoriasis.
✅ Deforming joint disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the office because of a recurrent rash. The patient noticed the rash for the first time after going in the water at the beach one month ago. She reports that since then, she has developed similar appearing pink and itchy rashes on her arms and legs that eventually resolve on their own. The patient works as a forest ranger at a national park. Past medical history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus and asthma. Current medications include ibuprofen and an albuterol inhaler, both as needed. The patient has seasonal allergies but no food intolerances. Temperature is 98°F (36.7°C), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 118/77 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for scattered expiratory wheezes. When ice is placed on the leg, a rash appears, as shown in the image:


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following terminologies best describes the dermatological findings seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s skin finding is consistent with urticaria, a dermatologic disorder characterized by pruritic wheals that form after mast cell degranulation. Urticaria can occasionally be triggered by certain methods, such as application of an ice pack in this case; wheals can form due to cutaneous mast cell degranulation and release of proinflammatory mediators after cold exposure of the skin. Wheals are often described as pale red, raised, pruritic bumps that can occur anywhere on the surface of the skin.

Wheals should be differentiated from papules and plaques, which are solid elevated skin lesions that lack the characteristic well-defined erythematous margins observed in wheals. Moreover, wheals typically disappear on their own within 24 hours, unlike papules and plaques. The shape of wheals can vary, presenting as round, polycyclic (overlapping circles), annular (ring-shaped), or geographic (like a map) shapes.



Option Analysis

❌ Papules:
Incorrect: Papules are defined as less than one centimeter, solid, elevated skin lesions with no oozing fluid. They are characteristically seen in acne or a mole. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
❌ Plaques:
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions less than one centimeter in diameter. They are most commonly seen in association with psoriasis. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
✅ Wheals:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Patch:
Incorrect: A patch is a flat skin lesion greater than one centimeter in size that differs in color from surrounding skin (e.g. congenital nevus). This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.
❌ Macule:
Incorrect: Macules are described as flat, less than one centimeter changes in skin color that are usually seen in tinea versicolor or exemplified as freckles. This patient’s urticaria is suggestive of a different dermatological condition.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a painful vesicular rash on his face, elbows, and trunk for two days. His parent states the patient had a “flare-up of dryness and itching” in the same region for which high-potency topical corticosteroids were started five days ago. Family history is significant for asthma in his mother. Temperature is 38.05°C (100.5°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows an irritable child with erythematous, scaly, crusted lesions on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and on the trunk. Examination findings of the face are shown:


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

The presentation of this patient is most likely a complication of which of the following?
questions.solution:
This child’s presents with a painful vesicular eruption, fever, and a history of recent treatment with an immunosuppressive agent (corticosteroids). This presentation is highly suggestive of eczema herpeticum, a herpes simplex virus 1 infection (HSV-1). This is a rare but severe complication of atopic dermatitis, which is a likely cause of a flare of dryness and itching in this patient.

Atopic dermatitis (AD) is an immune-mediated inflammatory skin condition that commonly affects children, but it is also seen in adults. Major risk factors include a family history of atopy (e.g. asthma) and a loss-of-function mutation in the flaggrin (FLG) gene, which normally helps in maintaining the epidermal skin barrier. The disrupted skin barrier increases the exposure to antigen, resulting in a type I hypersensitivity reaction. The clinical presentation of AD varies among infants and children/adults:

  •  Infants: dry, itchy erythematous scaly, crusted lesions on extensor surfaces (e.g. elbows), trunk, cheeks and scalp; it spares the diaper area. 
  •  Children/Adults: lichenification of plaques in flexural areas.
Diagnosis is made based on history and clinical appearance of the lesions. Laboratory investigations may reveal elevated IgE levels and peripheral eosinophilia. Treatment options include avoiding triggers (excessive bathing, dry environments, stress, overheating) and application of topical emollient, with or without topical corticosteroids.  

Option Analysis

❌ Seborrheic dermatitis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic dermatitis ranges in presentation from mild scaliness (dandruff) in the scalp to involving a wide area of skin with well-demarcated, erythematous, greasy, scaly lesions. Crusting of lesions and the development of painful vesicular eruption is not typically observed.
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is an immune-mediated hyperproliferative skin disorder that can result in well-demarcated erythematous lesions with silver-scaling plaques and pruritus. Although extensor areas of the elbows are involved, it usually does not affect children or complicate into a vesicular eruption.
❌ Seborrheic keratosis:
Incorrect: Seborrheic keratosis usually presents as a waxy, “stuck on” lesion on the face or trunk, mostly in elderly patients. Scaly, erythematous, crusted lesions are unlikely.
✅ Atopic dermatitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lichen planus:
Incorrect: Lichen planus presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. It usually affects the ankles and the volar surface of wrists. Involvement of the trunk and extensor surfaces with erythematous vesicular eruption suggests an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old man comes to the office because of itching over his shins for the past few months. The itching is unrelenting and is now interfering with his sleep. He has used several over-the-counter ointments, which have not helped. Past medical history is noncontributory. He is sexually active with a female partner and uses condoms consistently. He has a previous history of IV drug use in his early 20s. Physical examination shows multiple, well-healed track marks on his arms. Examination findings of the shins are shown below.



Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

Complete blood count is within normal limits. Further testing reveals elevated serum aminotransferase levels. This patient’s condition is associated with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
This young man presents with pruritic, purple, polygonal plaques and papules on the lower extremities without improvement from over-the-counter ointment. He is most likely suffering from lichen planus (LP), an immune-mediated disorder resulting from CD8-positive T-cells activating against basal keratinocytes. LP is found to be associated with hepatitis C virus infection and various drugs including diuretics (e.g. thiazides) and antihypertensives (e.g. ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers). This patient’s history of IV drug use and laboratory testing revealing elevated serum aminotransferase levels (AST, ALT) suggest an underlying hepatitis C infection. The various clinical presentations of LP are as follows:

Cutaneous LP particularly affects the skin of the ankles and wrists and appears as a papulosquamous eruption defined by 6 Ps.



Oral LP (Fig A): Mucosal involvement manifests as lace-like Wickham striae and hypergranulosis affecting the buccal mucosa.


Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons
Fig A

  • Genital LP usually presents as violaceous papules affecting the glans penis in men and the vulva in women. 
  • Nail LP (Fig B) primarily affects the nail matrix and can range from nail dystrophy or complete nail loss.

 Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons
 Fig B

  •  Lichen planopilaris affects the hair follicles of the scalp and results in alopecia if left untreated. 
Diagnosis is made on clinical appearance and is confirmed on biopsy findings of a “saw-tooth” shaped dermo-epidermal junction (presence of lymphocytes) and a thickened stratum granulosum or hypergranulosis.



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Human papillomavirus (HPV):
Incorrect: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is most commonly associated with warts, which are small cauliflower-like outgrowths that can appear on any part of the body. HPV can be transmitted via direct skin- to-skin contact or by unprotected sexual activity. This patient’s low-risk sexual behavior and pruritic, purple plaques on the lower extremities are atypical.
✅ Hepatitis C virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV):
Incorrect: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is found to be associated with severe seborrheic dermatitis, disseminated molluscum contagiosum, recurrent herpes zoster, and sudden-onset psoriasis; however, none of these conditions present with the pruritic, purple, polygonal plaques seen in this patient.
❌ Trichophyton rubrum:
Incorrect: Tinea corporis is caused by Trichophyton rubrum and usually presents as a pruritic, scaly, erythematous patch with central clearing and raised annular borders. Purple, polygonal plaques, as seen in this patient, are inconsistent with the diagnosis.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect:Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis can secondarily lead to scarlet fever, which presents with a sand-paper-like, blanching, diffuse, erythematous rash, in addition to circumoral pallor and strawberry tongue. The rash typically affects the groin and armpits initially. Pruritic, purple plaques on the lower extremities suggest an alternative association.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of altered mental status. He appears disoriented and agitated. Per review of the medical record, past medical history is notable for hypertension. He has a 35-year smoking history and consumes 5-7 beers per day. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 148/55 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is oriented to self but not place or time. His pupils are equal and reactive to light, and fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing is performed and shown below. Which of the following additional findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Calcium oxalate crystals on urine microscopy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and disorientation. Laboratory testing reveals an increased osmolal gap (equation can be found below) and anion gap metabolic acidosis. These findings are suggestive of ethylene glycol poisoning.


Ethylene glycol can be found in antifreeze, engine fluids, and brake fluids. It is a toxic, colorless, and odorless liquid with a sweet taste. Ethylene glycol toxicity usually develops when it is consumed as a substitute for ethanol. Initially, patients will experience altered mental status, abdominal pain, and vomiting. Over time, alcohol dehydrogenase metabolizes ethylene glycol to glycolic acid and oxalic acid. Glycolic acid is toxic to renal tubules, and oxalic acid binds calcium, causing hypocalcemia and calcium oxalate crystal formation. As a result, patients may develop flank pain, hematuria, and oliguria.

Laboratory testing will reveal metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap, and increased osmolal gap (ethylene glycol is osmotically active).

Treatment options include fomepizole, a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, or ethanol, which has a higher affinity for alcohol dehydrogenase than ethylene glycol. Both treatment options prevent the further breakdown of ethylene glycol into its toxic metabolites. Furthermore, sodium bicarbonate can be administered to alleviate the acidosis, and some patients may require hemodialysis.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.

  

Option Analysis

❌ Radiopaque pills on abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: This answer choice is suggestive of iron poisoning. Iron poisoning often develops in children after accidental ingestion. Although iron toxicity can present with an anion gap metabolic acidosis, an osmolal gap is usually absent. Moreover, affected patients will typically present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and gastrointestinal bleeding.  
✅ Calcium oxalate crystals on urine microscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increased serum and urine ketones:
Incorrect: This answer choice suggests diabetic ketoacidosis. However, this patient is euglycemic and does not have a history of diabetes mellitus.  
❌ Prolonged QT interval on electrocardiogram:
Incorrect: A prolonged QT interval can be seen in patients with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity. Patients will also present with anticholinergic symptoms such as mydriasis, increased body temperature, dry mouth, tachycardia, and flushed skin. In contrast, this patient does not have anticholinergic symptoms, making TCA toxicity unlikely.  
❌ Elevated carboxyhemoglobin level:
Incorrect: Elevated carboxyhemoglobin levels are usually observed in association with carbon monoxide poisoning. A history of exposure to fire or exhaust is usually present. Although carbon monoxide poisoning can present with altered mental status, it would not typically cause an anion gap metabolic acidosis or increased osmolal gap.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain for the past week. The patient has also been experiencing frequent nausea and vomiting since symptom onset. He started a new job at a medical instrument manufacturing company three weeks ago. Past medical history is significant for exercise-induced asthma. Family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals erythema of the conjunctiva and oral mucosa. Wheezing is heard on auscultation of the lung fields. Which of the following is the most likely precipitating factor of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, as well as signs of pulmonary irritation (e.g., cough, shortness of breath, chest pain). These symptoms, in combination with the patient’s occupation, are concerning acute mercury poisoning.

Mercury poisoning can occur due to consumption of seafood, amalgam-based dental fillings, or occupational exposure (such as medical device manufacturing). Acute toxicity can present with gastrointestinal symptoms, such as severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, as well as pulmonary symptoms, such as cough, dyspnea, and chest pain, which may lead to interstitial pneumonitis. Patients may also have mucocutaneous symptoms such as conjunctivitis, stomatitis, and dermatitis. Chronic exposure, on the other hand, may present with the triad of tremors, neuropsychiatric problems (e.g., fatigue, memory loss, irritability), and gingivostomatitis.

Mercury poisoning can be diagnosed by measuring mercury levels in the blood or urine. Treatment involves eliminating the exposure source, intravenous fluids, respiratory support, and chelation therapy with dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) or dimercaprol.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen overdose:
Incorrect: Individuals with acetaminophen overdose presents with nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Severe intoxication can cause liver damage and elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient who recently started a job at a medical instrument manufacturing company presents with respiratory symptoms in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Organophosphate exposure:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning presents with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. Atropine competes with acetylcholine at muscarinic receptors and reverses the muscarinic symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with acute mercury toxicity secondary to occupational exposure.  
❌ Lorazepam overdose:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepine overdose presents with nervous system depression and occasionally respiratory depression. However, benzodiazepine overdose would not account for this patient’s shortness of breath, cough, and chest pain, in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
✅ Mercury exposure:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethylene glycol ingestion:
Incorrect: Ethylene glycol poisoning presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered mental status. However, this patient who recently started a job at a medical instrument manufacturing company presents with respiratory symptoms in addition to nausea, vomiting, and conjunctival and mucosal erythema, which are suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office because of two months of progressive fatigue, poor appetite, and numbness in his hands and feet. He works at a glass factory and has been experiencing a painful burning sensation in his distal extremities and weakness while gripping tools for the past two weeks. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has been taking homemade herbal medications for the last 5-years. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals areas of hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation over the neck. There is a thickening of the skin on the palms and soles. Neurologic examination shows decreased sensation in the hands and feet. Upper and lower extremity deep tendon reflexes are 2/5. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has peripheral neuropathy, variable skin pigmentation, and hyperkeratosis. Laboratory testing is notable for pancytopenia and mild transaminitis. In combination with his history of consuming homemade herbal medications and working at a glass factory, these findings suggest chronic arsenic poisoning. The patient should be started on dimercaprol therapy.

Arsenic is a metal found in herbicides, pesticides, and water. Acute arsenic poisoning can occur if someone ingests large quantities of the substance. Chronic arsenic poisoning can occur due to occupational exposures (e.g., metal smelting, agriculture, mining, glass manufacturing) or consumption of contaminated water and foods (e.g., herbs, rice). Arsenic is taken up by erythrocytes, where it binds to sulfhydryl groups and impairs various enzymatic reactions, leading to impaired cellular respiration.

Acute toxicity can present with diarrhea, vomiting, garlic breath, and QT-interval prolongation. Chronic exposure can cause sensorimotor neuropathy, skin hypopigmentation or hyperpigmentation, and hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles. Mees lines, which are horizontal striations on the fingernails, may also be present.

Diagnosis is based on history, physical examination, and measurement of urine arsenic excretion. Other laboratory abnormalities include pancytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Chelation agents such as dimercaprol or succimer can treat arsenic toxicity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acetaminophen intoxication:
Incorrect: Patients with acetaminophen overdose can present nonspecific symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and malaise. Although severe intoxication can cause liver damage and elevated liver enzymes, it would not typically cause peripheral neuropathy, dyspigmentation, hyperkeratosis, or pancytopenia.  
❌ Organophosphate poisoning:
Incorrect: Organophosphate poisoning can present with symptoms of cholinergic hyperactivity such as bradycardia, miosis, bronchorrhea, salivation, and lacrimation. This patient’s symptoms are inconsistent with those of organophosphate poisoning.  
❌ Lorazepam overdose:
Incorrect: Affected patients can present with nervous system depression and occasionally respiratory depression. Benzodiazepine overdose would not typically cause peripheral neuropathy or cutaneous changes.  
✅ Arsenic poisoning:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ethylene glycol poisoning  :
Incorrect: Patients with ethylene glycol poisoning can present with abdominal pain, vomiting, and altered mental status. In contrast, the peripheral neuropathy, skin dyspigmentation, and hyperkeratosis seen in this patient is instead consistent with a different exposure.
